HIS is a very misunderstood game. When in first came out in the late 00s it was a novelty, there wasn't another game like it. However it was very niche, and still is. Its good point is that it is fun if you go into it with an open mind and no predetermined expectations.

The only thing HIS has in common with Warthunder is the same as what Assassin's Creed and Dead Space have in common. They are both games.

EDIT: This is a day after my initial review. The Steam version is worse than the original version, and their website is formatted so badly, I thought I was at the wrong place. Seriously, that is NOT English (even if you do set it to America/UK) This was fun when I was 8 and had no other games to play and was a F2P scrub.

(Original): I remember playing this game back when I was in elementary school on Windows XP. I even invited some of my friends to play with me. I had 2 main characters, both high levels. Then came along more realistic simulators, WoT, World of Warplanes, and the most popular (and my favorite), WarThunder. Comparing this game to War Thunder is like comparing the 1998 Half-Life to Portal 2 or Counter Strike:Global Offensive; it's dated, but it doesn't stop there. When I was younger, I didn't notice all of the horrid mis-translations(or just bad grammar) because I knew no better.

The gameplay is either a tad interesting or boring out of your mind. You can play with up to 4 online players (friends, or an open lobby) or by yourself in a mission that has bad AI with the standard guns you get in the game, which suck. Somtimes you can pickup drops from enemies witch go into your inventory, which you can use to upgrade or build equipment or IS equipment, that being said, there is a rarity scale for items. On the topic of Missions, there are 8 chapters, each of them holding about 20 missions each, with (almost)the same exact enemies. You can also participate in online tournements, where a LV1 person will sometimes glich into existence and TAKE OUT YOUR TEAM OF WELL 'EXPERIENCD' LV70s FOR SOME REASON(because there are supposed to be level gaps in the tournement lobbies you can participate in).

Not much else to say. It's like WarThunder, it has squads n'stuff and you shoot down other players sometimes.
P.S. To get my old account back, I had to install the online launchers game over the Steam version so it would give me the option to login on startup. Good example of a game where I don't want to give it a good or bad rating, but I'll say this: try it, and read the bad aswell as the good reviews and decide for yourself.

If you are looking for a laid back plane game, this is it, it isnt high graphics with realistic anything, just very simple fly and shoot missions, campigns and pvp. When I say arcade, it`s not even a joke, if you are looknig for realism go elsewheres, if you are looking for a simple to play game with a large option of planes to pick and play with just for fun, shotoing down planesi n various missions, then this is for you. In short if you are just looknig for a fun laid back game, this is for you, if you are someone expecting it to be a game competeing with War Thunder then you need not even look causr this is nothing like it aside from world war two planes. The missions are 1-8 players going up agaisnt various air and ground npcs with various objectives. Leveling in this game isnt bad, but being free to play they do tempt you with items you can buy with cash to give you an edge, like any other free to play game does. The plane models arent horrible, once again this game is arcade in almost every sense, controls are other keyboard, mouse, or controller and are very simple. You can swamp out various engines, propellers, armor, and weapons on ANY plane you have and is only limited to the type of the plane and your lvl. Personally i love this aspect cause no plane is the same, except outward apperances which soon may also change.

Over all it is just a funny arcade war plane game, notihng like war thunder so if that is what you are expecting then you wont like this at all. Very simple game with various things to do from leveling, getting planes, modifying planes, and doing missions. This is a game for someone who doesnt really have a lot of time for say fifthteen minute long missions and just want to play for fun, yes you can put hours into it, but the leveling is fairly quick and missions typically are quick and easy, not all of them seeing how they all differ. Not high graphics so you dont need a fancy gaming computer to run it. I would reccomend this to any casual gamers looking for a simplistic game that still has vairous things to do and can play for a couple of hours and you feel like you`ve made progress.

reviewText:
At first when I saw all the negative reviews, I didn't want to download this game, but then I saw a positive review saying that the game isn't meant to be realistic or like war thunder in any way. So I thought: Well since most of the negative reviews hates on the game's flight models and stuff, and the game isn't supposed to be realistic, and it's actually supposed to be an MMORPG but with planes, I decided to give it a shot.
Here are the pros and cons:

Pros: - Easy to learn
- Don't have to pay to win or to have fun
- Tons of planes
- Tons of missions
- Missions can be played in co-op, or alone
- PvP and PvE modes
- Can run smoothly on any computer
- No lag
- Easy to level up
- Easy to get new upgrades
- Not a grind fest, making money and getting unlocks and rewards is quick and easy.
- Lots of parts and items to upgrade your plane with
- Storage warehouse for un-used items
- Tons of Quests that gives you bonus rewards
- Extremely detailed tutorial quests to teach you how to play the game
- Fun to play

Cons: - The game's graphics look like it's from 1996
- The damage model is just a simple health bar, no individual components that can take damage
- Can't do barrel rolls or loops
- No plane engine sounds
- All guns sounds the same
- You can fly through enemies without taking damage
- Only 3 different death animations for planes, 1: The plane's engines starts burning, and a wing breaks off, and the plane spirals to the ground and explodes. 2: The plane's engines starts burning, and the plane spirals to the ground and explodes. 3: The plane doesn't burn or anything, it just spirals to the ground and explodes.
- No throttle control

Overall I find it fun to play the game, even though the controls and gameplay is really simple and easy, and the graphics are from the 1990's. It just feels fun to play, and there's a lot of content. Even more content than some AAA games. It has almost as much content as War Thunder. Lots of maps, planes, missions, weapons, upgrades, and so on. If this game had tanks like War Thunder, then I would say they have the same amount of content. It's still a great game though.

Long story short: Great game, great fun, tons of content, no grinding for money or levels, you should totally try it out!

Heroes in the Sky is a great game in my opinion.

I used to play it a long time ago, but with their migrations to their own host, therefore leaving GamesCampus, accounts were lost.  That was including mine, the popular Raptor1, in the fleet HIS Allstars, who did quite infact create the CONS (Coast of Norway Shadow abbreviation...)

If you just got it on Steam, not to worry, they MOST LIKELY won't take it off or move their account database.

Bad graphics?  So?  It's the gameplay that counts...

Brain-dead AI?  First of all, you are probably playing EUR1, and not doing a mission higher than Mediterranean on Ace.  Also, raids are pretty hard as well, you need at least more than five people if you want to complete them.

Planes not turning all of the way?  If you have a USB Joystick, they can.  What else could you flip it with?

I used to play it back in 2008, when War Thunder didn't exist and this was a really popular game.  It's the gameplay that counts, not the graphics or audio.

You have to spend more than an hour on this game if you want it to get super fun.  The beginning missions (EUR1 and EUR2) are so much easier, especially on the Rookie difficulty.  Once you go further, things get tough.  Also, PvP is quite fun to play.

Overall, I don't see why there is so much hate.  I think this game is really quite good, and it has its reasons to dislike, but are they good reasons?

UPDATE:
I have talked to GameUS, and they were willing to talk with me and discuss these issues.  Maybe the reason they tried to friend you was to help you become satisfied with the game?  Before being quick to judge, give the game and GameUS some time.  They are aware of lots of the bad English, and are trying to fix it.  After all, it's pretty good being that GameUS is in Seoul, Korea.  Like I said, just give it some time.

Also, notice that most of the people that had bad reviews played for less than two hours.  In two hours on League of Legends, I honestly had no idea what I was doing, but I still had fun anyway.  Also, remember that this is an arcade style game, and not a simulator.

Heroes in the Sky,

Is an old(er), arcade flying game with an MMO community geared towards the asian market. That's something that can be felt throughout the enitire game.
Translations might be a bit off, buttons might be placed in at a weird position and the overall feeling is not that of the regular Steam game.

A big no go for me is the pay to win style that gets across on the later missions. At some point you're not able to fly anymore because you spent all your energy and the only way to refill that energy is through buying some items or by waiting 24 real hours. And that's just bad.
But, on the other hand, that's what Heroes in the Sky is all about, like with any MMO; trying to get your money.
Until you hit that we want your money" part; you'll be having lots of fun with the many different planes

reviewText:
Now, before you make an assumption that I am 'just another twit who doesn't know the game', be advised that the time is just my Steam. I played this way before it was on Steam, immediately before school, etc, etc. I'd make an estimate of at least 50 or more hours spent.

This game is, to me, a good example of an arcade. It is not meant to be realistic; that would be for the simulators, like War Thunder, World of Warplanes, or DSC World. It is not meant to be realistic; it's meant to enjoy the murdering of your enemy as you spam machineguns and missiles (which are mildly seeking).

Those who complain about the graphical aspects...it's graphics suck. I will be blatantly honest, they are flat, and at times, they suck. The people do not look realistic. For all sakes, it is from 2007, and graphics aren't everything. That's like watching pornography for the good storyline. You are enjoying the gameplay...for all sake, people play Minecraft, Terraria, and others, and they do not have the best graphics. To me, that is just a plus...means my PC can actually run it.

I think this game is bombarded by twits who do not understand the concept nor the time; it was 2007.

11/10, I will continue to play.

EDIT

OK, so I've played it for a while and...this game is not the one I played before. Lemme explain.

There are multiple errors in the game. First off, and most apparent, is the grammar. This might not be such a great issue...but as I said, I played it before. The Gamescampus version did not have those issues, and changing what is clearly a done job to a worse job is not good. In addition, in the Axis tech tree, certain Japanese aircraft are named in German. That is NOT what you do, and annoying. Again, minor yet was not present in the previous version.

Next off is the 'supply missions'. This involves flying-about and going through floating boxes made of wood. This is random, to me. It's also not fun, because all you are doing is flying. No, that is not good gameplay.

Next is the gameplay actions. In certain missions, the GM can choose what they want to do. This usually involves certain class-oriented goals, like 'Attack retreating troops' or 'another target is spotted'. This, this I like. It provides a certain amount of choice in the player's day. However, there is one mission (d*mn me, but I don't remember it) where you can also choose 'supply crates found'. If you choose this, retreating troops appear, and vice versa. This, this I do not like.

Next is the AI. Before, it was OK that there was quality of quantity. However, I played, recently, the 'Weapons Testing' mission on Allies where one flies against ME-262s. For those who don't know, these are jet fighters Germany fielded near the end of the war. As such, they suck in a turning-battle, yet are amazing in a run-and-gun scenario. I'm in a prop plane. What do they do? Engage me in a turning-battle where I am guarenteed to win. This is annoying and easily moronic.

I also have some complaint on the faction numbers. Simply put, there are more Allies than Axis. This makes it extremely hard to play Axis, and extremely easy to play as Allies. This is something I, personally, don't like.

I have come to realize that, while the majority of twits don't understand it, those who do should understand that it was FAR better before, and this is an unacceptable downgrade.
